Silvan Floors boosts turnover thanks to new orders By IFrodsham | Posted: August 30, 2016 1 COMMENTS SHARES Front (l-r) are Directors Richard Brewster and James Iliffe Silvan Floors boosts turnover thanks to new orders X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (1) 
An upmarket floor maker is set to smash its turnover target after winning contracts worth several million pounds. 
Silvan Floors, of Thurlaston, has clinched a number of orders which are set to boost the company's turnover to £4 million next year. 
Directors Richard Brewster and James Iliffe said the company is well-placed to beat its five-year target which originally aimed to achieve turnover of £5 million by 2020. 
Richard said: "We had a five-year business plan where we had a specific turnover to hit by the end of the five years, which we hit in year two. 
"So we recrafted it and we're on target to hit the target again in year two. 
"We're taking on two staff this year and three next year."

The projects recently won include a deal worth £500,000 to make and install floors for luxury flat developer Buxmead, a £1.5 million project to supply oak flooring to an apartment complex in Victoria, London, and flooring for the private home of a Hollywood star in the Cotswolds, which was worth £150,000 to the business. 
Silvan Floors has also won a contract to supply a luxurious apartment block in Wembley, north London. 
The first stage of this work is worth £600,000 to £700,000. Once completed, it will be worth just shy of £2.5 million. 
In two weeks, Silvan Floors will also be opening a showroom in Fraser Street, downtown Vancouver, with carpet firm Burritt Brothers. Richard said: "We've started to do more exporting and with the new shop in Vancouver, we've got a contract in place for the Burritt Brothers to sell our products on our behalf. 
"We're currently working on projects in Hong Kong and Athens and we are going to do the floors for the Columbus Monte Carlo hotel in Monaco, which was previously owned by Formula One driver David Coulthard."

James added: "We're one of three or four companies in the world that do what we can do so we're getting a lot of interest from America in places such as Los Angeles and Boston. 
"We're now manufacturing for a large German company – so we've gone from manufacturing and importing in Germany to exporting for a large company out there." 
The directors said they aren't too concerned about the Brexit vote and are aiming to grow the export side of the business.James said: "We're hoping to double our export market in the next 12 months. 
"We're looking at Brexit in a positive manner. We're a proud British manufacturer and have become a part of the Make It British campaign. 
"We're winning contracts because we're British. British manufacturing has a great reputation overseas."
